reviewText: This is the other Shaw Bros movie I remember well from my childhood (the other being FIVE DEADLY VENOMS), and it's one of only three that has all the original cast members from that film. In other words, an essential Venoms.A gold shipment worth millions is due to set out for a famine area as government relief, but cash that tall always attracts trouble. The government contracts the Hu Wei Security Bureau to escort the shipment, and they send the mysterious Sheriff Hai Tao to help. Rounding out our group of heroes are the Batman-&-Robin-esque team of Long Axe and Short Axe, and a pair that makes this film something special for Venoms fans: The one actor that keeps the rest from being "full" venoms films is Wei Pak, who stars in this film as pompous, arrogant, yet ultimately heroic swordsman Li Qing Ming. He's a sterotypical "wandering swordsman in white" with a difference - a swordswoman fiancee who does her best to keep him from being honorable but stupid.But our heroes are up against the baddest bunch of gangstas there is - the Qi Sha, who are introduced in the opening credits sequence: Golden Arm, Silver Spear, Iron Robe and Copper Head. And about a zillion followers.The movie itself is a bit of a mess. There's a sloppiness to it, as though production had been very rushed and they used the first take that came out halfway decent. Don't be alarmed - it only shows in the first few fights. AThe sloppiness is confined to the production  the script is TIGHT. Also, by some miracle, the sloppier parts come early on, and the movie tightens up right along with the rising action. Each fight is literally better than the last, and I don't think more than five minutes go by without an action sequence. The humor works well - generally, Hong Kong comedy is something I ENDURE, but I enjoyed the highly-functioning yet ragingly alcoholic hero Hai Tao, played by Kwok Choi. When we finally meet the "mysterious" sheriff, he appears to be a simple drunk, then completely unreliable, maybe even psycho- he throws a colleague into a HOT OVEN. But there's a method to his madness, and when he finally faces off against the too-cool Golden Arm, you realize you were anticipating the HELL out the fight - it's just that the blistering pace gave you no time to think about anything. This is a movie you strap yourself into. Probably wear a hat. Scripted by the relaible Ni Kuang, there's a nice wuxia-type twist at the end, and it has one of the All-Time Great Final Lines of Dialogue.I say this a lot when discussing Venoms flicks, but...when Chiang Sheng and Lu Feng go at it, it always feels like a legit fight to the death (see FLAG OF IRON and MASKED AVENGERS). I always found that interesting, as Kwok Choi and Lu Feng were the two alleged to have on-set issues with each other. Whatever the reason it happens, the fight between Short Axe and Silver Spear is a thing of beauty.Tokyo Shock does this the way it should be done, but I d wish Linn Haynes were still around to have given us the commentary track this deserves.Groovy weaponry, bizarre fighting styles, freaky costumes (is that...David Bowie? Oh, wait it's the Silver Spear), clever twists, a breakneck pace, the funniest poisoning I've ever seen, a seriously funky soundtrack, and a Bad Guy who turns out to be not such a bad guy make TKWTGA...a blacklight poster come to life? An ur-superhero movie? Cirque du Slay? I DON'T EVEN KNOW! but I love it. And you probably will too.
summary: The Gas Pedal is Stuck, and the Bridge is Out

reviewText: Lo Meng plays the villain leader known as Golden Arm.He has a crew of other bandits that include Silver Spear,Iron Robe, Brasshead,and the Seven Hooks gang.They will stop a gold cargo from being delivered.Chiang Sheng,Sun Chien,Wei Pai,and Phillip Kwok play the heroes.Kid with the Golden Arm runs about 80 minutes,being one of the shortest Venom movies out there. Having more action and still able to keep a plot.It is a Venom fan must because all of the Venoms are in this movie and they have enough screentime.

reviewText: Chang Cheh and his venom mob chalk up another victory in the form of The Kid With the Golden Arm. I saw this film at the Aztec Theater in San Antonio, Texas when I was in single digits. Even after decades I could still remember characters and plot points. Lo Meng is the quintessential wuxia hero. When I think of old school kung fu, he is the archetype, the standard by which I judgeall other kung fu action heroes.A piece of my childhood reclaimed and entertaining enough that my children can watch and enjoy as well.

reviewText: This is one of my favorites.  Tons of great fights, most with weapons.  A lot of main characters killed off.  This flick is fun, imaginative, and exciting...the way a good martial arts movie should be.It starts with our heroes escorting a cargo of gold to a famine-stricken area, per government request.  You can't just take a load of money through the countryside and not expect the Chi Sah gang to take a stab at swiping it.  Led by Golden Arm (Lo Meng), the gang boasts a whole mess of tough guys with colorful names like Brass Head and Silver Spear.  Luckily, drunken "agent"(?) Hai To (Philip Kwok) is keeping close tabs on the gang, their progress, his ever-growing liquor tab, and the amount of honey-teriyaki marinade that will be needed to properly barbecue Wei Pai.I don't feel it's necessary to give out more information than that.  All the Venoms are on hand for this one.  In my opinion this is better than "5 Deadly Venoms".  I have seen about 5 of their movies and this is easily my favorite thus far.My only complaint is that this is not remastered and Celestial has yet to do so.  I will gladly purchase this again when that day comes.  That being said, there is nothing wrong with the picture quality and fans of kung fu will enjoy this immensely, providing you're not looking for much of a story.  Story?  What kind of kung fu fan are you?1979
summary: a lead script with golden results

reviewText: I have to say that the Venoms really dominated and made the genre of the "Kung-Fu" films. While I prefer to call them "Martial Arts/Hong Kong Cinema", this is one of the finest and most complete movies of that famous era.Kuo Chui, Wei Pai, Lo Meng, Lu Feng, The late Chiang Sheng(The Five Deadly Venoms) are all in this movie, and they are joined by many of  our favorite supporting cast members from their other films including the great Johnny Wang(still a very tough guy at 50+).This one has everything you want to see in a movie from this type or genre. It has some of the finest choreographed fighting sequences thanks to its very talented cast members. Phil Kwok(aka Kuo Chui) is now considered one of the greatest action directors in the film business in Hong Kong or Europe, and from me to him, you have a lot of fans in the US including me !The story has some unexpected twists from the Venoms.First Off, Ms.Lee, a female guest star, is unusual for Venoms films due to the strong feelings of producer Mona Fong, who felt that strong women characters in ancient China would be unrealistic. She was right, of course, however, modern trends all want to show us women with heroic characteristics and Ms.Lee's character is very likable and important in the movie.Secondly, we have a likable HERO in Lu Feng, who is cast very surprisingly as the evil leader of the Chee Saw gang. However, for all of his fans, he makes even a bad guy a hero in the end.Lo Meng reprises his undercover bad guy role as the Silver Spear who tries to turn Kuo Chui(Agent High-Toe) into a bad guy. Lo Meng a true master, not only was he a great fighter, but his characters made you feel he could convince others to follow him through low key, friendly persuasion.Chiang Sheng as "Short Axe" was just classic for him, and to be honest his death scene brought tears to my eyes knowing that he is gone from us in real life now too. Short Axe is a jovial, fun loving fighter, and Chiang was well known to be a man with a big heart. RIP brother Chiang.We also get to see Wei Pai in a role as the Swordsman. This is important because he did not star in as many movies with the other Venoms as they did with each other. Wei Pai, a gentleman in most of  his roles always gives us an air of honor, and higher standards. It would be interesting to know if Wei Pai did come from a upper class background prior to acting.Veteran Shaw Brothes actor and now director Johnny Wang gives another great "bad guy" appearance as the evil Iron Robe. For those in the know, he was the judge in 5 Deadly Venoms, and he also starred as a bad guy in the Ti Lung classic Avenging Eagle.A very important movie for Shaw Brothers and Martial Arts fans, this one is a classic by which others may be measured.
summary: A Top 5 Venoms Film with a complete storyline

reviewText: Don't know why it took so long but it has finally arrived. Classic Shaw Brothers/Venoms from start to finish. In 1978, Chang Cheh did this after "Invincible Shaolin" was complete. It was also the last film Wei Pai did with Chang before leaving for Golden Harvest. Everybody is present including Lo Mang as the "Golden Arm Kid", Lu Feng as Silver Spear, Johnny Wang as Iron Armor & Robert Yang as Copper Head. The story about Hu Wei Security transporting 20,000 taels of gold to a famine area & being intersected by the Deadly Valley (Chi Hsia) borrows a little from the 1969 Shaw film "Have Sword Will Travel" (both movies are directed & co-written by Chang though so it's OK.)  Instead of David Chiang we have Kuo Chui doing an amazing job as the "Sheriff of a Thousand Faces" Hai Tao. Awesome characters, great performances, esoteric costumes/weapons & tremendous fu from Robert Tai, Lu Feng & Chiang Sheng. Highlights include, literally, the final half-hour, as well as a great fight between Kuo Chui & Johnny Wang.  Tokyo Shock got it right - excellent transfer from the remastered Celestial version, this personal favorite of mine (along with "The 36th Chamber of Shaolin") never looked or sounded better. Uncut, widescreen, in Mandarin with remastered subtitles or a decent English dub & a good photo/still gallery.  This is the definitive version of this Chang Cheh classic.

reviewerName: morgoth "we lamas are traditional enemies of ...
reviewText: Golden arm(lo meng) is the head of a gang that is set on robbing this gold that is being escorted somewhere.  His goons, silver spear(lu feng), brass head(shaw's strongman, name not listed anywhere), and iron robe(lung wei, or johnny wang)with his iron fan are wanting the gold but there is also this HUGE respect thing going on.  Wei Pei plays this cool a-hole of a swordsman who just seems like he is in the movie to go around and prove himself.  But then he gets shown up and dick wei comes out of nowhere and hits him with the sand palm.  Then Phillip Kwok is introduced and his character was alright but his drunkiness really wasn't thoroughly explored.  But I am a nitpicker cause he was AWESOME.  And the fact I have like 5 guys that I am trying to decide who is my favorite character in this makes this a true kung fu classic.So we have an escort service of course to guard this gold to get it where it needs to go.  And PLENTY of traps set up by the gang.  The movie is only like 77 minutes long but it manages to put action to the screen for like at least an hour.  It was a true spectacle.  The fights are long, varied, and gory.  All the great things you have come to expect form chang cheh gets boosted up one notch in.  It seems stupid, but he actually manages to put together a good movie.  And the music was even a little different.  Now like all Cheh films, the end fight is made up of many fights but the very last one is truly one of the best I have ever seen.  LET THE LEGS FLY!!!!!!!!!!!!It seems like it was wire enhanced but I had to watch it a few more times just to fully appreciate this.  I don't want to tell you who the last fight is between, but when I mention the legs, it really only points to one guy, right?  Well, this other guy was close to this guy.  Sorry not to give names, but awesome movie and I can't allow myself to give anything away. And also, Chiang Shiang(little axe) has a great battle with lu feng, but I would be here all day if  I broke down all the fights.  THEY ARE ALL AWESOME!!!!!!I am reviewing the red sun version, and I have to say that I am not all that happy with this.  But I guess that is just casue I have been spoiled.  The version seems cut by at least one scene, it is not remastered, but it is  widescreened.  Not fully widesscreed, but we get a much better view of the action than say a pan and scan job.  But if you read my reviews you will see that I LOVE this red sun distributor.  I have master killer, five deadly venoms, etc... from them and they are all remasterd, but I just realized this doesn't say remasterd, just widescreed and it costed a few dollars less than their other releases.  So at least they always tell the truth and sometimes give you AWESOME extras.All in all, this is a top 2 or 3 cheng cheh movie for me.
summary: another 6 venomed classic, would say 7 venomed, but johnny wang doesn't fight too much in this.

reviewText: If you grew up when these movies use to come on the Saturday morning Martial Arts Classics, then you know how great they are.  Full of action, great stories, unparalleled martial arts abilities, and some even had some great humor in them as well. The Kid with the Golden Arm was definitely in the top ten martial arts films.  Golden Arm was a bona fide bad ass.

Led by the Lo Meng (The Toad) as Golden Arms.The fight scenes are surperb and Wei Pei (the snake) and Sun Chien (the scorpion) also appear in excellent roles. Seriously, a good Kung-Fu flick that you can watch over and over again.the renegade lives!

reviewText: I like pretty much all Venom movies.  But this one is one of my favorites.  It is your usual Venom fare.  Some of them good and some bad (unlike Invincible Shaolin where they are all good guys).  The bad guys all die and only some good guys live (don't want to give away who and how many). In my opinion, this may be Kuo Chui's (Lizard from the Venom movie) best movie.Basic story, the government (or rich people - can't truly figure it out) are sending gold to an area of China in desperate need of help.  They are concerned about the gold being stolen by a gang of thieves led by Golden Arm.  Besides getting help from some local top notch fighters, the government is sending one of their top agents to help.  The agent, though excellent, has one fault, he tends to be drunk (though don't expect the fights to appear drunken like with Jackie Chan in Drunken Master).As for DVD quality.  It was excellent (I have the one with Golden Arm and girl on cover).  On a blu-ray player, it upsized well and used the entire screen (black bars on top and bottom but full width) and it looked great.If you like any Venom movie, you will like this one.  If you dislike the Venoms, then stay away, it is more of the same.
summary: One of the best Venom movies
